MEMBERSHIP IN THESE CLUBS ALLOWS FOR RECIPROCAL USE OF OTHER RELATED VENUES WITHIN THE UNITED STATES. THESE RECIPROCAL AGREEMENTS ALLOW SENIOR ADMINISTRATION TO HOST QUALITY BUSINESS AND FUNDRAISING EVENTS OUTSIDE THE COMMONWEALTH OF PENNSYLVANIA.

THE EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES REVIEWS APPROPRIATE ANALYSES AND STUDIES PREPARED BY THE HUMAN RESOURCES OFFICE OR EXTERNAL SOURCES TO AID IN EVALUATING COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS AND STRATEGIES TO ATTRACT AND RETAIN QUALIFIED PERSONNEL FOR SENIOR EXECUTIVE ADMINISTRATIVE POSITIONS. THE COMMITTEE ANNUALLY REVIEWS AND APPROVES COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS FOR SENIOR ADMINISTRATORS AND OFFICERS OF THE UNIVERSITY. THIS REVIEW INCLUDES COMPARABLE MARKET DATA FOR POSITIONS AT OTHER HIGHER EDUCATION INSTITUTIONS. THE COMMITTEE REPORTS TO THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES THE TOTAL COMPENSATION PAID TO THE UNIVERSITY'S PRESIDENT AND VICE PRESIDENTS. THE COMMITTEE REVIEWS THE RECOMMENDATIONS OF, AND ADVISES, THE PRESIDENT AS TO THE INDIVIDUAL EMPLOYMENT CONTRACTS THAT ARE ABOVE AND BEYOND THE SCOPE OF THE UNIVERSITY'S BASE COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS STRUCTURE.

PART I, LINE 7, AND PART II, COLUMN B(II) AMOUNTS INCLUDED UNDER COLUMN B(II) ON SCHEDULE J REPRESENT AWARDS PAID OUT TO INDIVIDUALS ON THE BASIS OF MERIT. THE MERIT AWARDS ARE DETERMINED BY THE HEAD OF UNIT. CRITERIA FOR MERIT AWARDS FOR ALL CATEGORIES OF ACADEMIC, RESEARCH STAFF, ACADEMIC-RELATED AND SUPPORT STAFF, THE EVIDENCE FOR CONTRIBUTION TO THE ACHIEVEMENT OF THE UNIVERSITY'S STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES AND EXCELLENCE WILL CONSIST OF: -OUTCOMES AND RESULTS. -INDIVIDUAL'S BEHAVIOURS, SKILLS AND KNOWLEDGE. JUDGEMENTS WILL BE EVIDENCE-BASED, PRINCIPALLY THROUGH APPRAISAL PROCESSES CONSIDERING CRITERIA SUCH AS: -THE ACHIEVEMENT OF OBJECTIVES WHERE THESE PROVED TO BE UNEXPECTEDLY OR PARTICULARLY DEMANDING. -OUTSTANDING INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTION TO A TEAM. -SUCCESSFUL ADAPTATION TO CHANGE. -UNDERTAKING ADDITIONAL RESPONSIBILITIES (OTHER THAN SUBSTANTIAL PERMANENT CHANGES THAT WOULD JUSTIFY RE-GRADING). -CONTRIBUTION BEYOND REASONABLE NORMAL EXPECTATIONS FOR THE ROLE-HOLDER. ADDITIONAL INCREMENTS AND DISCRETIONARY POINTS MAY BE REWARDED ON THE ABOVE CRITERIA WHEN DEMONSTRATED OVER A SUSTAINED PERIOD AND ANTICIPATED TO CONTINUE.

A MINISTERIAL HOUSING ALLOWANCE IS AVAILABLE TO THOSE WHO QUALIFY. THIS BENEFIT IS COMPUTED BY THE MINISTERS AND PROVIDED TO TRINITY INTERNATIONAL UNIVERSITY. THE BOARD APPROVES THE CALCULATION AND INFORMS THE MINISTERS OF THE ANNUAL ALLOWANCE. THIS BENEFIT IS NONTAXABLE.

The President flew first class on one flight during the month of January 2014. This was due to the necessity of traveling while recovering from a medical condition. The College president's spouse is also an employee of the college, and therefore, travel costs for certain business related travel is covered for her. The president is provided a discretionary spending account of $6,000 (after tax) for contribution to charities, 501 (C) (3) organizations, or public causes of his choice. In order to effectively perform his duties as president, the president resides in housing provided by the College. The President's residence also services as a place for meeting with dignitaries and community leaders, receptions, meeting, and fundraising events. The college provides cleaning, lawn care, and other maintenance relating to the president's housing. A portion of the president's housing allowance is reported as taxable income. The college reimburses the President, Executive Vice President & Chief Advancement Officer, Provost & Vice President for Academic Affairs, Vice President of Legal Affairs & General Counsel, and the President of the School for online & Extended students & Extended Partnerships for membership dues and initiation fees relating to membership in any clubs that the board of directors requests them to join.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Part I, Line 1a: Relevant information in regards to selections on 1a.

ExplntnTxt: As outlined in the President's contract with the College, the President is required to live in a house provided by the College as part of his job as President. The house is physically located on the College's campus.

The Compensation Committee of the Board of Trustees approves the President's written employment contract on an annual basis. The approved written employment contract is approved by the full Board of Trustees and documented in the minutes. As deemed necessary by the Compensation Committee, an independent compensation consultant is used for input regarding the President's salary level as compared to other comparable positions.

The president's spouse occasionally travels with him to conferences or on other trips. This is typical of many college presidents and is expected. The college also provides living quarters on campus for the president which is also used for entertaining current and prospective donors and students as well as employees. The college also provides housekeeping services for the residence.

ExplntnTxt: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a The President and his wife live in a University house located on campus. They use the house for University meetings, receptions, and other related functions. University custodians clean the first floor common rooms but not the family private rooms. The University requires the Vice President for Student Affairs, three activity directors, and the Director of Buildings and Grounds to live in University-owned housing on or near the campus as a condition of employment.

THE PRESIDENT OF THE COLLEGE HAS A RESIDENCE PROVIDED TO HIM AS PART OF HIS COMPENSATION PACKAGE. IN ADDITION TO THE RESIDENCE, HOUSEKEEPING SERVICES, SUCH AS CLEANINING AND MAINTENANCE, ARE ALSO PROVIDED BY THE COLLEGE. LIMITED TRAVEL FOR THE PRESIDENT'S SPOUSE IS PROVIDED AS WELL.

As a condition of employment the President is required to live in housing supplied by the college. In addition, travel for her companion is provided when they are representing the institution at public functions across the country. All of the vice President's have a small discretionary fund with their individual departments. All expenses do require documentation and are not taxable to the individuals.

THE VERY REV. DR. JOSEPH H. BRITTON, DEAN OF BERKELEY DIVINITY SCHOOL, IS PROVIDED ON CAMPUS HOUSING AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE EMPLOYER.

The board approved compensation package for the President of the University includes a monthly housing allowance, and reimbursement of expenses for personal financial counseling and club dues. All benefits are included as taxable compensation in the W-2 and all such benefits have been approved as part of a reasonable compensation package as established by an outside compensation consultant.
There are several institutional incentive plans at various levels and are based on exceeding exempt purpose program goals. All plans comply with Title IV regulations.

Column C includes annual contributions to the TIAA-CREF retirement plan and the earned portion of a Rabbi Trust plan established by the Board on July 15, 2010. It was developed in response to the outside compensation firm's (Yaffe & Company, Inc.) finding that the Board had not provided adequate retirement funding for the President for the past three decades. The 457 plan is a qualified plan.

President has housing provided--(required to live on premises and the FMV of the rents are used in valuation of benefits), also some spousal travel and tax indemnification are included as part of contract. Social membership for President and Provost included in valuation.

As a requirement of the position, the President and his family reside in a college-owned house, which is not a taxable benefit. The Vice President of Student Affairs and his family reside in a college-owned house, the benefit of which is taxable and the value is recorded on his W-2. The college pays for membership of the President at a local country club for entertaining donors. The President reimburses the college for expenses incurred by his family for non-college related activities.
The compensation committee is made up of members of the Board of Trustees.

By the nature of the position, the CEO is required to fulfill several obligations/commitments which may result in travelling first-class and/or charter to accommodate required appointments. Further his spouse may accompany him as well as dictated by her required presence for an event. The CEO has available to him a discretionary fund (budgeted each year) for assisting individuals and/or projects in need of support. Further, the CEO is required to reside in college-owned housing for the purpose of being a presence on campus and for entertainment purposes. As the result of living in a college-owned residence, the College provides, as with all campus buildings, light housekeeping. The position of CEO also requires membership in certain social/academic organizations and therefore, the college provides the dues/fees associated with that membership. From time to time the College utilizes the College President's personal residence for College events and housing of College guests.

The Prudential Committee (executive committee) of the Board of Trustees approves the CEO's annual salary. The Treasurer's Office secures salary information supplied by the Chronicle of Higher Education, From 990 of other organization, compensation consultants and written contract. This information is then provided to the Prudential Committee for their review and evaluation.
Depending on the levels of gift revenue, bonuses were paid.
The President of the College is the only person who received benefits listed in this section.

There is not a written policy because only the College President benefits. The governance committee reviews the compensation and benefit package for the College President based on input from market survey's and performance. The governance committee makes the final decision.

The College enters into performance based incentive programs with certain officers and key managers whereby incentives are awarded by the President and approved by the Trustees after evaluating the level of achievement of predetermined goals. The Trustees also enter into a preference based incentive program with the President and incentives are awarded by the Trustees after evaluating the level of achievement of predetermined goals for the President.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE J, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 1A
ExplntnTxt: UNDER IRC SECT 119(A) THE VALUE OF LODGING PROVIDED IN KIND TO AN EMPLOYEE (THE PRESIDENT) FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE EMPLOYER IS EXCLUDABLE FROM GROSS INCOME IF THE EMPLOYEE IS REQUIRED TO ACCEPT SUCH LODGING ON THE BUSINESS PREMISES OF THE EMPLOYER AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT. THE COLLEGE REQUIRES AND FURNISHES A HOME FOR THE PRESIDENT USE AS A CONDITION OF HIS EMPLOYMENT. THE PRESIDENT IS TO USE THE HOME TO ENTERTAIN OR HOLD MEETINGS FOR BOARD MEMBERS, VARIOUS COLLEGE EMPLOYEES, POTENTIAL DONORS, AND STUDENTS. THIS IS A SCHOOL POLICY AND IS PART OF HIS EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT. THE PRESIDENT HAS USED THE RESIDENCE EXTENSIVELY FOR COLLEGE BUSINESS. HE HAS AN OFFICE IN THE HOUSE SOLEY DESIGNATED FOR COLLEGE WORK THAT HE USES EACH DAY AND WEEKENDS. THE PRESIDENT ENTERTAINS THE TRUSTEES WHICH DROP BY CONTINUOUSLY THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. THE PRESIDENT WILL HOLD CABINET MEETINGS AT THE HOUSE PERIODICALLY. MEETINGS WITH COMMUNITY OFFICIALS OCCUR FREQUENTLY AT THE HOUSE. THE PRESIDENT MEETS POTENTIAL AND LONG TIME DONORS AT HIS HOME SEVERAL TIMES A MONTH TO SECURE CONTRIBUTIONS FOR THE COLLEGE. HE HOLDS A FRESHMAN SEMINAR CLASS AT THE HOME AT SEVERAL TIMES A MONTH. THE PRESIDENT HAS ALSO ALLOWED STUDENTS TO STAY AT THE HOUSE FOR SHORT STAYS WHEN NEEDED. HIS HOME IS ALWAYS OPEN TO STUDENTS TO DROP BY AND VISIT. THE PRESIDENT PERFORMS A MEANINGFUL PORTION OF HIS DUTIES AT HIS HOME.

The University paid membership dues for organizations, including National Association of Independent Colleges & Universities (NAICU), NW Commission on Colleges and Universities (NWCCU), and Oregon Alliance of Independent Colleges & Universities (OAICU).

The University has strong policies and procedures established in the University Accounting Department and a developed procurement policy. Although there isn't a specific policy which addresses payment of social dues for its Officers, there are policies and procedures for ensuring expenditures incurred are for business purposes. The membership fees are for business and thus were properly authorized and processed in the University Accounting Department.

The University also made severance payments totaling $8,075 and corresponding FICA payments totaling $618 to Celina Ratliff, VP for Human Resources and Organizational Excellence.

THE UNIVERSITY OWNS A PRESIDENTIAL RESIDENCE. BY CONTRACT, THE PRESIDENT IS REQUIRED TO LIVE IN THE RESIDENCE AND HOST REGULAR EVENTS FOR THE UNIVERSITY THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. THE UNIVERSITY PAYS ALL THE EXPENSES FOR THE PRESIDENT'S RESIDENCE. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO PAYS FOR THE PRESIDENT'S MEMBERSHIP TO THE LOCAL ROTARY CLUB. HE ATTENDS FOR COMMUNITY SERVICE, OUTREACH AND FUNDRAISING OPPORTUNITIES. A PORTION OF THE BENEFITS LISTED WERE TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION TO THE PRESIDENT.

THE EMPLOYEE WHO QUALIFIES FOR A SUPPLEMENTAL NONQUALIFIED RETIREMENT PLAN WILL EARN A FIXED AMOUNT OF CREDIT AND ELIGIBLE INTEREST TO HIS OR HER DEFERRED COMPENSATION ACCOUNT. THE RIGHT OF THE EMPLOYEE TO RECEIVE THE AMOUNTS IS CONTINGENT UPON HIS OR HER CONTINUED PERFORMANCE IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT.

PART I, QUESTION 1A Housing for the president is paid for by the university. The residence is close to the campus, and the President is required to live there and conduct university related business per his contract. The University provides a country club membership in the President's name that is used for business related entertaining. On occassion, the University has purchased first class commercial airfare for the President when his schedule and/or seat availability require it. The University does not provide charter air travel.

Linfield College provides housing for the President. He is required to live there as a condition of his employment and for the convenience of the employer. The college pays club dues to Michelbook Country Club, the University Club and the Arlington Club as part of the President's role (e.g. fundraising, external relations, meeting space, etc.) The college occasionally pays travel costs for the president's spouse if she is attending alumni gatherings or other events where it benefits the college to have the president and his wife present.

Reimbursements for companion travel are allowed with a bona fide business purpose and approval of an officer. THE UNIVERSITY, AS PART OF ITS EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION PROCESS HAS AGREED TO PAY CERTAIN COSTS SUCH AS HOUSING, AUTOMOBILE AND SOCIAL CLUB DUES AND INCLUDES THESE PAYMENTS IN THE EXECUTIVE'S COMPENSATION, AS TAXABLE INCOME. THE INDIVIDUALS AUTHORIZED TO RECEIVE SUCH PAYMENTS ARE ISOLATED TO SENIOR OFFICERS SUCH AS THE PRESIDENT, PROVOST AND THE EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT. THE UNIVERSITY OWNS A RESIDENCE WHICH IS USED FOR SCHEDULED UNIVERSITY EVENTS, FUNDRAISING ACTIVITIES AND OTHER KEY MEETINGS INVOLVING UNIVERSITY OFFICIALS, TRUSTEES AND GUESTS. AS A CONVENIENCE TO THE UNIVERSITY, THE PRESIDENT LIVES ON THE SECOND FLOOR OF THE RESIDENCE AND PAYS THE UNIVERSITY RENT BASED ON THE FAIR MARKET VALUE OF THE RENTAL SPACE DISCOUNTED FOR THE SCHEDULED UNIVERSITY USAGE.

THE HUMAN RESOURCES DEPARTMENT OF THE UNIVERSITY COLLECTS WAGE AND BENEFIT INFORMATION OF UNIVERSITIES OF SIMILAR SIZE AND STATURE FOR ALL SENIOR OFFICER POSITIONS BASED ON THE INFORMATION IN THE SURVEYED SCHOOLS' FORM 990. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO COLLECTS ANNUAL WAGE AND COMPENSATION INFORMATION FROM THE ANNUAL COLLEGE AND UNIVERSITY PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATION (CUPA) SURVEY FOR USE IN SALARY DETERMINATIONS. BASED ON THESE SURVEYS, THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES APPROVES CHANGES TO THE SALARIES OF DEANS AND ABOVE. RECOMMENDED CHANGES MADE BY THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE TO THE PRESIDENT'S SALARY ARE REVIEWED BY THE FULL BOARD OF TRUSTEES.

ANGIE HEER $ 5,041 COMPENSATION IS REPORTED ON THE FORM 990 IN THE YEAR THE COMPENSATION IS EARNED BY OR AWARDED TO AN INDIVIDUAL, EVEN IF THE COMPENSATION IS NOT PAID TO THE INDIVIDUAL, IS NOT FULLY VESTED, OR IS SUBJECT TO SUBSTANTIAL RISK OF FORFEITURE. IF COMPENSATION IS EARNED OR AWARDED IN ONE YEAR BUT PAID IN A LATER YEAR, THEN THE COMPENSATION IS GENERALLY REPORTED A SECOND TIME ON THE FORM 990 IN THE YEAR THE COMPENSATION IS PAID TO THE INDIVIDUAL. AS A RESULT OF THE REPORTING REQUIREMENT, AN ORGANIZATION COULD BE REQUIRED TO REPORT THE SAME COMPENSATION ON FORM 990 IN TWO DIFFERENT YEARS.

A) First Class or Charter Travel - The Institution's travel policy establishes that the President may travel in first class and those Officers that travel with the President on official business trip may travel in Business Class. Also, the Institution pays travel expenses in Business Class for the President and Vice-President of the Board when travelling to Board related activities or seminars such as the Board's Annual Seminar, the Association of Governing Board's Conference, among others. B) Travel for Companions - The President's spouse accompanies him at the Institution's expense when he travels on official business trip and so do the spouses of the Members of the Board and Officers on certain business activities. C) Housing Allowance or Residence for Personal Use - The Institution owns a property that is used as the President's residence. The rent market value of this property is classified and reported as part of the President's compensation. D) Payment for Business Use of Personal Residence - The President owns a property contiguous to the Institution's property provided as residence. The Institution covers expenses related to business activities at this property. E) Health and Social Club Dues or Initiation Fees - The Institution covers the cost of membership at local hotels to be used for activities and representation expenses by Officers. F) Personal Services - The Institution covers the costs of a maid services at the President's residence.

Travel for companions - The seminary encourages and reimburses officers of the seminary to travel with their spouses when the spouse has a legitimate business purpose such as travel for a donor visit. The circumstance occurs on an infrequent basis. The following were reimbursed by the Seminary for spousal travel, which was not included in their compensation as all had a legitimate business purpose for the travel: six officers, one former officer, and one trustee. Housing Allowances - Housing allowances are annually reviewed and approved by the Executive Committee of the seminary. Two officers and one former officer are ministerial employees which received nontaxable housing allowances. Four officers, one former officer, and two employees received housing allowances which were included in their taxable compensation.

Michael A. Milton received a severance package valued at $133,462 during calendar year 2013 for his faithful service as Chancellor of the Seminary. This package was intended to help him with living expenses, cost of health insurance and some assistance for retirement.

Schedule J, Part I, Line 7 Officers of the University participate in a board of trustees approved executive compensation program which includes an incentive compensation plan. The annual amount is capped at a percentage of their salary. The plan is based on the achievement of certain programmatic goals and objectives for the officers' units and the university. The goals are non-revenue related goals. The plan is approved by the compensation committee and the committee reviews and approves the annual awards based on the performance achieved on the agreed-upon goals.

ExplntnTxt: IN RECOGNITION OF THE UNIQUE ROLE OF THE PRESIDENT IN REPRESENTING THE UNIVERSITY, THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS OF JOHN CARROLL UNIVERSITY REQUIRES THE PRESIDENT, AS A CONDITION OF THEIR EMPLOYMENT, TO LIVE IN A RESIDENCE CONTIGUOUS TO THE UNIVERSITY AND SUITABLE FOR CARRYING OUT THEIR ROLE AND REQUIRED OFFICIAL DUTIES. AS PART OF THEIR OFFICIAL DUTIES, THE PRESIDENT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR EXTENDING OFFICIAL HOSPITALITY TO IMPORTANT VISITORS AND GUESTS IN CONJUNCTION WITH OFFICIAL FUNCTIONS (I.E., CAMPUS ACTIVITIES, ALUMNI AND ADVANCEMENT EVENTS, ETC.). MAID SERVICES ARE PROVIDED TO THE PRESIDENT FOR THE UNIVERSITY OWNED RESIDENCE IN WHICH THEY RESIDE. NO TAXABLE INCOME IS IMPUTED FOR THESE BENEFITS. THE UNIVERSITY'S TRAVEL EXPENSE POLICY PROHIBITS THE PURCHASE OF FIRST- CLASS AIR TRAVEL OR THE EQUIVALENT AT THE UNIVERSITY'S EXPENSE. HOWEVER, FIRST-CLASS TRAVEL OR THE EQUIVALENT IS PERMITTED IN CERTAIN LIMITED CIRCUMSTANCES IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE PRESIDENT'S EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT WHICH HAS BEEN REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY THE BOARD OF DIRECTOR'S EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE.

ON JULY 1, 2008 THE UNIVERSITY ENACTED A QUALIFIED PRIVATE 457(B) DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN FOR CERTAIN EMPLOYEES WITH ANY EMPLOYER CONTRIBUTIONS TO BE MADE ON A DISCRETIONARY BASIS. THE UNIVERSITY MADE NO CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE 457 PLAN IN FISCAL 2014. ANY AND ALL CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE PLAN IN FISCAL YEAR 2014 WERE VOLUNTARY EMPLOYEE CONTRIBUTIONS. THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNIVERSITY, FR. ROBERT NIEHOFF, SJ, IS A JESUIT PRIEST AND MEMBER OF THE SOCIETY OF JESUS (SJ), A RELIGIOUS ORDER OF THE CATHOLIC CHURCH. IN KEEPING WITH HIS RELIGIOUS VOWS, THE PRESIDENT DOES NOT RECEIVE DIRECT COMPENSATION FROM THE UNIVERSITY. COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS FOR SERVICES PROVIDED BY MEMBERS OF THE SOCIETY OF JESUS ARE PAID DIRECTLY AND IN THE AGGREGATE TO JOHN CARROLL JESUIT COMMUNITY CORPORATION, RATHER THAN TO EACH MEMBER INDIVIDUALLY. GENERAL BOARD OF DIRECTORS MEETINGS ARE HELD AT LEAST THREE TIMES ANNUALLY, WITH EACH MEETING GENERALLY HELD OVER A TWO-DAY PERIOD. IN ADDITION, BOARD COMMITTEES, INCLUDING ACADEMIC AFFAIRS AND PLANNING, AUDIT, CORPORATE GOVERNANCE, DEVELOPMENT, EXECUTIVE, FINANCE, HUMAN RESOURCES, INVESTMENTS, NOMINATING, PLANNING, PROPERTIES AND STUDENT AFFAIRS, MEET AS NECESSARY BUT AT LEAST THREE TIMES ANNUALLY.

As a condition of employment, the President is required to reside in, along with immediate family, in an on campus residence (President's residence). The College maintains, at its expense, the President's residence, grounds and provides utilities, security and housekeeping services based on the needs of the President and his immediate family.

THE COLLEGE PAID FOR HEALTH AND SOCIAL CLUB DUES OR COUNTRY CLUB DUES FOR ONE OF THE OFFICERS/HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEES LISTED IN PART VII. CANISIUS WILL ONLY REIMBURSE A BUSINESS EXPENSE WHEN ALL THREE OF THE FOLLOWING IRS REQUIREMENTS ARE MET: 1) THE EXPENSE MUST HAVE A BUSINESS CONNECTION (I.E., THE EXPENSES MUST BE INCURRED WHILE PERFORMING SERVICES ON BEHALF OF THE COLLEGE) 2) THE EXPENSE MUST BE ADEQUATELY SUBSTANTIATED BY THE EMPLOYEE WITHIN A REASONABLE PERIOD OF TIME; AND 3) THE EMPLOYEE MUST RETURN ANY EXCESS REIMBURSEMENT OF ALLOWANCE WITHIN A REASONABLE PERIOD OF TIME. A PORTION OF THESE DUES WERE TAXABLE BASED ON THE PERCENTAGE OF NON-BUSINESS TO BUSINESS USE FOR EACH EMPLOYEE. THE COLLEGE "GROSSED UP" THE APPLICABLE NON-BUSINESS EXPENSES AND INCLUDED IN THE EMPLOYEES' W-2 AS ADDITIONAL TAXABLE COMPENSATION.

The President's residence is available for College-related business and entertainment on a regular and continuing basis. The President's contract also provides him a club membership to be used exclusively for College business.

The President has a supplemental nonqualified retirement plan that has been approved by the Board of Directors. The terms of this plan are set forth in the written contract of the President that has been signed by the Chair of the Board of Directors.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Housing allowance or residence for personal use
ExplntnTxt: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a The President is being provided a house as a convenience to the College to allow him to conduct business affairs and be available 24/7 to respond to emergent situations that may arise. The residence is for personal use and to entertain trustees, employees, students, donors, and guests of the College. IRS instructions to Form 990 require that the fair market value of housing provided to employees by their employer be reported on Form 990, Part VII, Section A and Schedule J, Part II. As a condition of employment, the President of Elmhurst College is required to reside at the college owned residence at 360 Cottage Hill Avenue in Elmhurst. The residence serves both as a personal residence as well as a venue for regular carrying on of College business. The College has determined that the value of the use of this personal residence is not considered taxable income to the President as provided for in Internal Revenue Code Section 119. For tax year 2014, the value of the President's use of the residence is conservatively estimated to be $59,835. During tax year 2014, the President, Stephen Alan Ray made the residence his home for the year. Schedule J, Part II, Column (D) includes $59,835 of value associated with the use of the residence provided by the College.

Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Travel expense reimbursement for companions is only allowed for the President as per his contract. According to his contract, when Dr. Ray's spouse is required to attend an event in which Dr. Ray is representing the College on official College business, the business related travel expenses for Dr. Ray's spouse will also be reimbursed by the College. The spouse's travel is not considered taxable when the purpose is to conduct business on behalf of the college. This contract is reviewed by the Human Resources Committee and approved by the full Board of Trustees.
Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a An outside service is used as needed to maintain or to provide any other cleaning services necessary for the business function of the President's house.
THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT A HOUSING ALLOWANCE. THE VALUE OF THIS BENEFIT IS INCLUDED IN THE PRESIDENT'S TOTAL COMPENSATION.
STEPHEN JONES AND KIRK PETERSON, FORMER PRESIDENTS, RECEIVED SEVERANCE AGREEMENTS.

HOUSING ALLOWANCE/PERSONAL SERVICES: THE COLLEGES PROVIDE PRESIDENT SCRIMSHAW WITH A HOME IN TROY AND REQUIRE ITS USE AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE COLLEGES. THE TOTAL ESTIMATED VALUE OF THE ANNUAL USE OF THE RESIDENCE IS $50,000 OF WHICH $33,500 IS ESTIMATED TO BE THE VALUE OF PERSONAL USE AND IS REPORTED AS A NONTAXABLE BENEFIT IN FORM 990, PART VII AND SCHEDULE J, PART II.

The president's spouse peridically travels with the President to official college functions. The spouse's travel is paid by the College when the office college function dictates such participation such as donor relations and alumni events. The President is provided a residence in which he/she is required to live. The residence is regularly used for college functions. An estimated fair value of $17,395 and $11,412, respectively for current President Jay Simmons and former President John Byrd, has been included under Part VII, Section A, column F of the Form 990.

The Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees consists of the Treasurer, Secretary and Chairman of the Board, which are all independent members of the Board of Trustees. The Committee is charged with reviewing and approving the compensation and benefits for the President. The Committee uses comparability data such as a survey issed to several private colleges regarding total compensation for a president conducted by an independent compensation consultant and salary data for private college administrator positions provided by a state association of independent private colleges. The Committee is required to inform the full Board of Trustees of all provisions and elements of the President's compensation.

A DISCRETIONARY SPENDING ACCOUNT IS PROVIDED TO THE PRESIDENT. IT IS USED FOR COLLEGE EVENTS, PRESIDENTIAL TRAVEL, AND TO SUPPORT ANY UNANTICIPATED COLLEGE NEEDS. IT IS NOT FOR PERSONAL USE. ALL EXPENDITURES ARE REQUIRED TO BE DOCUMENTED. IN ADDITION, THE PRESIDENT WAS PROVIDED A MEMBERSHIP AT A LOCAL COUNTRY CLUB TO BE USED FOR FUNDRAISING ACTIVITIES AND OTHER COLLEGE BUSINESS. USE OF THE MEMBERSHIP IS SUBSTANTIATED. LASTLY, THE COLLEGE PROVIDES HOUSING AND WEEKLY HOUSEKEEPING SERVICES TO THE PRESIDENT FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE EMPLOYER SO THAT THE PRESIDENT CAN PERFORM ESSENTIAL COLLEGE BUSINESS AND ACTIVITIES AT THE HOME.

The President is required to live in housing provided on campus. The value of this housing is excluded from taxable income. In addition, a nonqualified retirement plan was established for the President, and a portion of this contribution contained a tax gross up intended to offset the future tax liability when the plan becomes vested and taxable.

The compensation of the President is reviewed annually by the Board of Trustees. As part of this process, the President's compensation is compared to a cohort of similar institutions, the Great Lakes College Association. The result of the deliberations and decisions are documented in a statement of salary letter sent to the President and the Director of Human Resources.

A nonqualified retirement plan was created by the College during the fiscal year and the College agreed to fund the plan for President Wilson-Oyelaran. The College funded the plan on July 1, 2014 in the amount of $71,817. Included in this amount was $39,099 which represented an overpayment of previous years' contributions into the President's 403(b) retirement plan. This amount had been removed from the President's 403(b) retirement account during the year in order to preserve the qualified tax status of the College's retirement plan.

THE UNIVERSITY'S TRAVEL POLICY PROVIDES THAT EXPENSES INCURRED BY SPOUSES ARE NOT REIMBURSABLE UNLESS THE SPOUSE IS TRAVELING FOR A BONA FIDE BUSINESS PURPOSE AND THE TRAVEL HAS BEEN APPROVED. ANY EXCEPTIONS TO THE POLICY REQUIRE APPROVAL BY THE APPROPRIATE UNIVERSITY OFFICER. ALL SPOUSAL TRAVEL IS PROCESSED UNDER THE PROVISIONS OF THE TAX DEPARTMENT'S SPOUSAL TRAVEL POLICY WHICH PROVIDES FOR EVALUATING THE TAXABLE COMPONENT, IF ANY, OF THE TRAVEL AND THE APPROPRIATE TAX TREATMENT AND REPORTING. APPROPRIATE APPROVALS IN ACCORDANCE WITH POLICY ARE REQUIRED PRIOR TO REIMBURSEMENT. SPOUSAL TRAVEL EXPENSES WERE PAID AND WERE REPORTED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION FOR R. GERALD TURNER AND BRAD CHEVES. ALL GROSS-UP PAYMENTS HAVE BEEN APPROPRIATELY APPROVED IN ACCORDANCE WITH UNIVERSITY POLICY PRIOR TO PAYMENT. EMPLOYEES WHO RECEIVED GROSS-UP PAYMENTS FOR PAYROLL TAXES WHICH WERE REPORTED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION WERE WILLIAM DILLON AND ALBERT NIEMI. THE PRESIDENT IS REQUIRED UNDER HIS EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT TO RESIDE IN THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED RESIDENCE. THERE IS A POLICY REGARDING REVIEW/APPROVAL OF SOCIAL CLUB DUES. THE UNIVERSITY HAS ESTABLISHED A REPORTING PERIOD OF NOVEMBER 1 THROUGH OCTOBER 31 FOR REPORTING PERSONAL USE OF A CLUB AND CALCULATING THE PERSONAL PORTION OF DUES THAT SHOULD BE REPORTED AS TAXABLE INCOME. ANY PERSONAL CHARGES AT SOCIAL CLUBS ARE REIMBURSED TO THE UNIVERSITY WHEN THE BILLING IS RECEIVED, PRIOR TO PAYMENT. THE EMPLOYEES WHO HAD PERSONAL AMOUNTS REPORTED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION RELATED TO SOCIAL CLUB DUES ARE R. GERALD TURNER, BRAD CHEVES, LORI WHITE, CHRIS REGIS, ALBERT NIEMI, AND LARRY BROWN. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES SERVICES SUCH AS LANDSCAPING AND RESIDENTIAL REPAIRS AND MAINTENANCE FOR THE PRESIDENT'S RESIDENCE, CONSIDERING THEM NECESSARY AND APPROPRIATE FOR HIS USE OF THE FACILITY FOR BUSINESS FUNCTIONS AS THE RESIDENCE IS A UNVERSITY OWNED ASSET. THE PERCENTAGE OF THE MAID'S COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS RELATED TO PERSONAL SERVICES WAS REPORTED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION TO R. GERALD TURNER.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE J, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 5A
ExplntnTxt: THERE IS ONE PERSON LISTED IN FORM 990, PART VII, WHO RECEIVED AN INCENTIVE COMPENSATION BONUS. THE ELIGIBILITY FOR AND THE AMOUNT OF THE PAYMENT IS DETERMINED BY TWO COMPONENTS: A QUANTITATIVE MEASURE OF THE PERFORMANCE OF THE UNIVERSITY'S INVESTMENT POOL AGAINST AN APPROPRIATE BENCHMARK AND A QUALITATIVE MEASURE BASED ON FACTORS SUCH AS RISK MITIGATION, QUALITY OF DECISION MAKING AND CONTRIBUTIONS TO ADVANCEMENT OF THE ENDOWMENT.

PAYMENTS TO THE ORDER ARE MADE IN LIEU OF THE PRESIDENT'S SALARY, WHICH IS DETERMINED BY THE TRUSTEES. THE FORMER HEAD COACH OF BASKETBALL MICHAEL BUOANAGURO RECEIVED A SEVERANCE PAYMENT IN THE AMOUNT OF $207,374.

On-campus housing is provided to the President as a condition of employment and is non-taxable under IRC-119. Dues paid at a local private club allow the President's Office to host college functions at that facility since the club does not allow corporate memberships. Because the President does not make personal use of the club, the benefit is considered non-taxable.

The College has written compensation guidelines for the President and Officers. Compensation for each is benchmarked to that of peers at colleges in the Associated Colleges of the Midwest and the Great Lake Colleges Association. Information about level of reward at other national Carnegie IIB colleges is reviewed. Data from the Chronicle of Higher Education on presidential salaries is also reviewed. Annual goals, objectives and strategic initiatives are set for the President by the Board of Trustees.

The Board of Trustees established a 457(f) Plan for the President of the College for the period June 1, 2011 through June 1, 2014. Partial vesting occurs after June 1, 2013; full vesting occurs after June 1, 2014. Interest rate is an average daily WSJ Prime. During fiscal year 2013-2014, $95,886 was accrued to the Plan.

THE DISCRETIONARY SPENDING ACCOUNT FOR AN EMPLOYEE IS PART OF THE NORMAL TAXABLE WAGES PAID TO THE EMPLOYEE AND IS INCLUDED AS PART OF THE EMPLOYEE'S TAXABLE INCOME. COUNTRY CLUB DUES ARE PROVIDED TO CERTAIN EMPLOYEES AS A MEANS TO THE COLLEGE EXPANDING ITS CHARITABLE PURPOSE. ANY PORTION OF THE DUES ATTRIBUTABLE TO THE PERSONAL USE BY THE EMPLOYEE ARE ADDED TO THE EMPLOYEE'S W-2; ONLY THE PORTION ALLOCABLE TO THE BUSINESS PURPOSE OF THE COLLEGE ARE ALLOWED.

EXECUTIVE RETENTION BONUS AGREEMENT GARY BRAHM, CHARLES BULLOCK AND SASKIA KNIGHT (EXECUTIVES) PARTICIPATE IN A SUPPLEMENTAL NONQUALIFIED 457(F) PLAN(AKA THE EXECUTIVE RETENTION BONUS PLAN), EFFECTIVE FEBRUARY 14, 2013. UNDER THE TERMS OF THE PLAN, THE BONUS IS CALCULATED AT 2% OF THE UNIVERSITY'S EXCESS SURPLUS FOR THE FISCAL YEAR JUNE 1, 2016 THROUGH MAY 31, 2017 (BASE YEAR), CAPPED AT THE GREATER OF THE EXECUTIVE'S HIGHEST ANNUAL BASE SALARY DURING THE BASE YEAR OR DURING THE PRIOR FISCAL YEAR. IN ADDITION, THE EXECUTIVE WILL RECEIVE A PAYMENT EQUAL TO THE PRESENT VALUE OF A SERIES OF PAYMENTS THAT WOULD BE MADE ON THE NINE CONSECUTIVE ANNIVERSARIES OF THE LAST DAY OF THE BASE YEAR, DISCOUNTED AT 3% PER ANNUM. A ONE-TIME DEFERRAL OPTION IS AVAILABLE TO THE EXECUTIVE TO ELECT JUNE 1, 2021 THROUGH MAY 31, 2022 AS THE BASE YEAR FOR THE BONUS AMOUNT.

SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 1A: First Class Travel - although it is the University's general practice to only pay for coach airfare, air travel other than coach (either first or business class) for officers and key employees is limited to either destinations outside the continental U.S. or when first or business class airfare is the only available airfare based on necessary travel dates. University policy requires additional documentation in the case of first or business class airfare to document the reason of the additional expense. Charter Travel - the University charters aircrafts for the purpose of transporting University athletic teams to various intercollegiate athletic event locations. In instances where a University employee and/or their family member travels on a University chartered flight, without a University business purpose, the University follows the rules under IRS Regulation Section 1.61-21(g) to determine the taxable value, which may be zero, of the chartered travel provided to the employee and/or their family member. Travel for Companions - the University occasionally pays for the travel of a staff member's spouse. These instances are generally limited to situations where either the spouse's travel is considered to have a University business purpose or as part of a staff member's services agreement with the University. The University further limits spousal business travel for instances where it believes their presence is in the best interests of the University and does not tax these amounts as additional compensation. The University does tax and report, as additional compensation, spousal travel provided as part of a staff member's services agreement and where there is no University business purpose for the travel. Additionally, on rare occasion a staff member's spouse may accompany a DePaul athletic team on a chartered aircraft, if excess seating is available. Please see the above Charter Travel disclosure for additional details regarding such instances. Tax Indemnification and Gross-up payments - such payments are generally provided based on the provisions of an employee's services agreement with the University and are included in column B (III) of Part II. Housing Allowance or residence for personal use - personal use of housing is generally based on the provisions of an employee's services agreement with the University. The value of the housing provided is not taxable to the individual to the extent it is a condition of their employment and necessary to carry on their duties. The value of housing, which is provided, but not as a condition of employment or necessary to carry on their duties, is taxable to the individual and reported in Schedule J, Part II as other reportable compensation in Col B (III). Health Club or Social Club or Initiation fees - such payments are generally provided based on the provisions of an employee's services agreement with the University. Payments for non-business use of such items are taxable to the individual and reported in Schedule J, Part II as other reportable compensation in Col B (III). Personal Services - such payments are generally provided based on the provisions of an employee's services agreement with the University. Payments for such items are taxable to the individual and reported in Schedule J, Part II as other reportable compensation in Col B (III).

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Written policy regarding payment or reimbursement
ExplntnTxt: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1b The items indicated for Line 1A, other than first class travel, charter travel, and travel for companions, are generally provided pursuant to an employee's service agreement with the university. Where appropriate, the amounts associated with the items are included in the total compensation as determined under the rebuttable presumption procedures adopted by the University for determining compensation for disqualified persons. Please refer to the Schedule O explanation for Form 990, Part VI-B, Line 15 for a description of the university's process for determining compensation for disqualified persons.

Schedule J, Part I, Line 7: For those individuals listed in form 990, part VII, section A, line 1a, who are eligible, bonuses are paid pursuant to their service agreement with the University. Such agreements generally contain either a dollar or percentage of base salary limit up to which the individual is eligible to receive as a bonus for a fiscal year. The compensation for the President is established by the Executive Compensation Committee of the Board of Trustees ("Comp committee"). The Comp Committee engaged an independent consultant to help benchmark executive-level salary and benefits at institutions comparable to Hendrix College. Following that study, the Comp committee established the Salary of the President. In future years, the Comp Committee will engage and independent consultant from time-to-time to re-establish benchmarks of the comparable group of institutions. In years where no outside consultation is engaged, the board may utilize the Hendrix College VP of Human Resources to gather benchmarking.

First Class Travel - In general, it is the college's policy that first class travel is not authorized for college employees traveling on college business. However, in recognition that the president typically works during flights, attends directly to business upon arrival, and cannot schedule in time for adequate rest, the board of managers has approved the use of first class travel for the president on domestic and international flights over three hours in length. This policy extends to the president's spouse when he or she accompanies the president on business travel. For all other employees (faculty and staff), first class travel must be pre-approved by the president or his/her designate. Travel for companions - In certain authorized circumstances the college will pay, or will reimburse for the travel, meals and expenses of the spouse/partner of an employee under the college's accountable plan. Reimbursements are considered taxable income to the employee unless the companion travel is 1) for a bona fide business purpose, 2) directly benefits the college, and 3) is properly documented and approved. Any spouse/partner travel other than the president must be approved, in advance, by the president or his/her designate. Tax gross-up - Retirement payments to employees may include a gross-up for a portion of the benefits paid. Residence Requirement - As a condition of employment the PresidenT, the Dean of Students & Vice-President Development & Alumni Relations maintained their full time residence in College-provided housing and used the residence for College business and entertainment purposes. Social club dues - Membership dues were provided to three New York University clubs to be used primarily for business purposes (entertainment / travel). The President and the Dean of Student Life are provided non-taxable housing as a condition of employment. The College pays for landscaping and cleaning services at the President's house, which is owned by the College, due to the fact that certain College functions are held at the President's house. The benefit is not taxable to the President and it is part of the house maintenance. The College maintains a membership at a country club, under the name of the President. Certain officers and key employees are provided with a cell phone allowance which is grossed up.

On an annual basis, the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees reviews the President's salary. Most recently, in August 2014, a nationally recognized consultant was engaged to conduct a compensation analysis for the President, Vice President and Dean positions. Their report was submitted to Board Chair in August 2014. Recognizing the uniqueness of Olin College, they used four groups in their analysis: * National Private Independent Colleges and Universities with Significant Engineering Programs of Comparable Complexity to Olin * National Private Independent Colleges and Universities with Bachelor, Master's or Doctorate Programs of Similar Size * Predominantly Northeast Regional Top Liberal Arts Colleges * Private Independent Colleges and Universities in Massachusetts with Bachelor, Master's or Doctorate Programs of Similar Size For each group, the consultant analyzed base salary, total cash compensation and total compensation for the 25th, 50th, 75th and 90th percentiles and adjusted the market data to a common effective date of July 1, 2014. The Executive Committee used this data to develop a recommendation for the President's compensation which was reviewed and approved by the full Board of Trustees. The President used this data to develop recommendations for the compensation of the Vice Presidents and Deans which were reviewed and approved by the Executive Committee. Salary increases for other key employees, based on performance, followed the same criteria and process for other employees. All decisions regarding compensation are approved by independent persons and all deliberations and decisions are substantiated contemporaneously.

For University non-aligned employees, merit based compensation may be granted as either a base salary increase or a one-time bonus. Qualifications for receiving a bonus include performance exceeding expectations or taking on additional duties due to staff vacancies or temporary absences. For the compensation of the University's President, the bonus amount (if any) is determined by an employment agreement along with a review and approval of the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees, who are all independent of the President. It is noted that the bonus payments in calendar year 2013 for the President represented merit bonus payments for fiscal year 2012 and fiscal year 2013. In the case of all other officers and other key employees, the bonus amount (if any) is determined via the same process as other compensation for officers and other key employees, including review by the University's President, who is independent of the other officers or key employees.

PEPPERDINE UNIVERSITY HAS A INCENTIVE COMPENSATION PLAN FOR CERTAIN KEY EXECUTIVES. UNDER THE PLAN, UPON ACHIEVEMENT OF CERTAIN EXPECTATIONS AND GOALS AND AT THE DISCRETION OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS, THE PARTICIPANT WILL RECEIVE A UNIVERSITY CONTRIBUTION TO THE PLAN FOR THAT PLAN YEAR. UNIVERSITY CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE PLAN BECOME GRADUALLY VESTED BEGINNING WITH THE LAST DAY OF THE 3RD PLAN YEAR FOLLOWING THE CONTRIBUTION AND VEST 100% AT THE COMPLETION OF THE 7TH PLAN YEAR FOLLOWING THE AWARD. Dr. George Martin, President, received a housing allowance and reimbursement for life insurance per employment contract. Both the housing allowance and life insurance are taxable.

George E. Martin: The University established a non-qualified deferred compensation plan under IRS Code Section 457F for the purpose of providing a retirement benefit for the university president, George E. Martin. Under the terms of the plan, the university agreed to establish a non-vested retirement account in a financial institution of the university's selection in the name of the university on behalf of the president; make an annual contribution to the retirement account during the term of the plan; invest the account balance and distribute the account balance to the president in accordance with the occurrence of specific events. The president has no rights to or interest in the retirement account prior to the date the account becomes payable to the president under the terms and conditions set for in the plan. The president's right to the retirement benefits is non-vested and forfeitable prior to the payment date. The retirement account is the property of the university at all times prior to the payment date. The university accrued $45,480 and paid $85,000 into the plan in the current reporting period. The president will become 100 percent vested in and entitled to payment of the retirement account at his normal retirement date; upon termination for disability or death; other than cause and voluntary cause for good reason as defined. The president forfeits all interest in the retirement account in the event of termination for cause or voluntary termination for other than good reason as defined.

George E. Martin: Included in Column B (iii) is a taxable housing allowance of $45,000, taxable automobile allowance of $4,068, taxable long-term disability insurance of $380, taxable reimbursements of $12,000 and employee deferred amount under section 457b plan of $23,000. The payments of the taxable reimbursements, automobile allowance, long-term disability insurance and housing allowance are made pursuant to the terms of the contract with President Martin and the university.

AN EVALUATION OF PERFORMANCE AGAINST GOALS IS CONDUCTED AT THE CLOSE OF A FISCAL YEAR TO DETERMINE THE LEVEL OF ORGANIZATIONAL AND INDIVIDUAL PERFORMANCE OF THE CEO AND SENIOR EXECUTIVES SO AS TO DETERMINE MERIT AND INCENTIVE PAY ACTIONS. MARKET DATA FOR BASE SALARY, TOTAL CASH COMPENSATION AND TOTAL COMPENSATION IS PROVIDED BY AN INDEPENDENT THIRD PARTY TO THE COMMITTEE AND REFLECTS A MARKET BASKET OF SIMILARLY SIZED ORGANIZATIONS WITH COMPARABLE EXECUTIVE POSITIONS. UPON REVIEW AND DISCUSSION OF THE RELATED DATA AND INFORMATION THE COMMITTEE TAKES ACTION WHICH IS RECORDED IN THE MEETING MINUTES WHICH ARE THEN FILED FOR FUTURE REFERENCE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 7, Non-fixed payments
ExplntnTxt: THE PURPOSE OF THE LANCASTER GENERAL HEALTH (LG) ANNUAL INCENTIVE PLAN (THE PLAN) IS TO REINFORCE STRATEGIC PERFORMANCE PRIORITIES FOR SENIOR MANAGEMENT AND MANAGEMENT EMPLOYEES AND TO ENCOURAGE THE HIGHEST LEVEL OF PERFORMANCE IN THE DELIVERY OF HEALTH CARE SERVICES. AS A REWARD FOR EMPLOYEES' CONTRIBUTIONS TO LANCASTER GENERAL HEALTH'S SUCCESS, THE PLAN PROVIDES THE OPPORTUNITY TO EARN MEANINGFUL INCENTIVE COMPENSATION BASED ON THE PERFORMANCE OF LANCASTER GENERAL HEALTH AND THE INDIVIDUAL PARTICIPANTS. SPECIFICALLY, THE PLAN IS DESIGNED TO: FOCUS PARTICIPANTS ON THE ACHIEVEMENT OF ORGANIZATION GOALS RELATED TO PEOPLE, SERVICE, QUALITY/SAFETY, FINANCIAL AND GROWTH; PROMOTE AND FOSTER A TEAM ORIENTED CULTURE; STRENGTHEN LANCASTER GENERAL HEALTH'S ABILITY TO ATTRACT AND RETAIN SUPERIOR TALENT, RECOGNIZE AND REWARD ACCOMPLISHMENTS THAT CLEARLY ADVANCE THE ORGANIZATION'S MISSION, AND DRIVE STRATEGIES; PROVIDE INCENTIVE AWARDS THAT CAN BE ADJUSTED ANNUALLY FOR DIFFERENT BUSINESS CONDITIONS AND BUSINESS PLAN PRIORITIES WITHOUT CHANGING BASIC DESIGN FEATURES OF THE PLAN; AND PROVIDE ANNUAL INCENTIVE OPPORTUNITIES WITH DUE CONSIDERATION TO THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE INTERMEDIATE SANCTIONS LAW AND THE REGULATIONS THERE UNDER. NON-FIXED PAYMENTS TO PERSON LISTED IN PART VII, SECTION A, LINE 1A WERE PAID BY THE COLLEGE AND RELATED ENTITY, LANCASTER GENERAL HOSPITAL (EIN# 23-1365353).

The President of Roger Williams University and Roger Williams University School of Law is compensated by the University. The President's compensation is contractually set and is reviewed by the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees of Roger Williams University, all members of which are independent of the President. The Executive Committee's review currently includes, but is not limited to the use of comparability data and other outside consultants.
The President of Roger Williams University participated in a University 457(f) plan and $25,000 was accrued under the plan in calendar year 2013.

For School of Law non-aligned employees, merit based compensation may be granted as either a base salary increase or a one-time bonus. Qualifications for receiving a bonus include performance exceeding expectations or taking on additional duties due to staff vacancies or temporary absences. For the compensation of the University's President, the bonus amount (if any) is determined by an employment agreement along with a review and approval of the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees, who are all independent of the President. It is noted that the bonus payments in calendar year 2013 for the President represented merit bonus payments for fiscal year 2012 and fiscal year 2013. In the case of all other officers and other key employees, the bonus amount (if any) is determined via the same process as other compensation for officers and other key employees, including review by the University's President, who is independent of the other officers or key employees.

The Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees chaired by the Board Chairperson deliberates to determine the President's compensation. Each member of the compensation-setting body is a disinterested party. Jesuit members of the Executive Committee recuse themselves from the salary deliberations. Salary data obtained from the Association of Colleges and University Personnel Administrators, the Association of Jesuit Colleges and Universities and an executive search firm database is used to determine compensation comparability. The decision of the compensation-setting body including terms of the compensation, the date approved, members of the compensation-setting body present during the discussion of the compensation and voting members, comparability data relied on and the source of the data and an affirmation that all members were free of any conflict of interest is documented and retained by the Secretary of the Board of Trustees.

- The universitys School of Medicine is organized into major Departments. Each department has a faculty compensation plan that provides guidelines to the Chair of the Department for setting annual compensation of the individual faculty members. Three of the five highest compensated employees listed in Part VII, Section A of the Form 990 are faculty in a department that had salaries determined under departmental guidelines that provide for base salaries that are fixed payments. In these departments however, there are elements of compensation under the guidelines that are not fixed payments or determined by fixed formula. The Chair of the Department determines, in full or in part, the amount of this element based on the employees performance. Further, there is an element expressed as a percent of net surplus generated by the efforts of the employee. The universitys Chief Investment Officer also receives a fixed payment based on the net earnings of an activity of the university. See discussion of Part I, line 7 below for further information.

- An incentive arrangement between the university and its Chief Investment Officer was amended and restated during fiscal year 2012. The agreement provides for three components of compensation two of which are based upon a fixed formula, and one of which is based on qualitative factors. The level of the latter component is determined at the discretion of a governing board under authority assigned by the university Board of Trustees to oversee management of the universitys endowment.

- The Executive Vice Chancellor for Administration,the Executive Vice Chancellor for Academic Affairs Provost, the Chief Investment Officer CIO, the Vice Chancellor for Admissions, the Vice Chancellor for Public Affairs, the Vice Chancellor for Students, the Vice Chancellor for International Affairs, the Vice Chancellor for Human Resources and the Vice Chancellor and Chief Information Officer received payments under initial employment agreements during fiscal year 2014. None were a disqualified person with respect to the university prior to entering into their employment agreements. The employment agreements with these individuals provided for a substantial portion or all of the compensation reported in Form 990, Part VII. All amounts, except for an amount paid under the incentive agreement with the CIO discussed above, are fixed payments and subject to the initial contract exception described in Regulation 53.4958-7a3.

- The 2013 compensation payments refered to in line 8 above were subject to rebuttable presumption procedures described in Regulation section 53.4958-6c but the initial contracts under which they were paid were not.

- Column C - The retirement compensation reported for officer Wrighton includes, among other amounts, the annual increase in value of a defined benefit plan. The university has agreed to supplement officer Wrightons retirement income contingent on continuing service as Chancellor, based on an annual accrual of 3 of average earnings.

EMPLOYEES ARE REIMBURSED FOR BUSINESS EXPENSES THAT RELATE TO THE PRACTICE OF MEDICINE. THE TOTAL AMOUNT REIMBURSABLE IN A GIVEN FISCAL YEAR IS DETERMINED BY THE RESPECTIVE CHAIRPERSON. ALL REIMBURSEMENTS ARE SUBJECT TO APPROVAL BY THE CHAIRPERSON OR THEIR DESIGNEE. FOR AN EXPENSE TO BE ELIGIBLE FOR REIMBURSEMENT, IT MUST BE ALLOWABLE "IN ACCORDANCE WITH GENERALLY ACCEPTED ACCOUNTING PRINCIPLES AND ALLOWABLE TO A PRACTITIONER AS A DEDUCTIBLE COST OR EXPENSE UNDER CURRENT FEDERAL INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE GUIDELINES." DOCUMENTATION OF EXPENSES FOLLOWS IRS GUIDELINES. EXPENSES ARE NOT PROCESSED UNLESS THEY HAVE COMPLETE DOCUMENTATION. EXPENDITURES THAT ARE $25,000 OR GREATER, UNPRECEDENTED, OR UNUSUAL, WILL REQUIRE PRIOR APPROVAL FROM THE PURCHASING AND ASSET MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE.

PART II, LINE 1 THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES ON CAMPUS HOUSING FOR ITS PRESIDENT FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE UNIVERSITY; ESTIMATED MONTHLY RENTAL CHARGE IS $4,000 OR $48,000 ANNUALLY, AND IS INCLUDED AS A NONTAXABLE BENEFIT IN COLUMN D. IN ADDITION, ESTIMATED PERSONAL COST RELATED TO MAID SERVICE FOR THE HOUSE IS $2,496 WHICH IS INCLUDED AS TAXABLE INCOME. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED FIRST CLASS TRAVEL FOR THE PRESIDENT FOR ONE TRIP ON UNIVERSITY BUSINESS DURING THE YEAR. THE FIRST CLASS TRAVEL WAS APPROVED IN ADVANCE BY THE VP FOR BUSINESS AND FINANCE.

PART I, LINE 7 & PART II, COLUMN B(II) PURSUANT TO HER EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT, THE PRESIDENT SHALL BE CONSIDERED ANNUALLY BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES, FOR A BONUS WITH A TARGET OF 15%, AND A MAXIMUM OF 30% OF THE BASE SALARY. THE AMOUNT OF THE BONUS SHALL BE DETERMINED BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE BASED ON ITS ASSESSMENT OF THE PRESIDENT'S PERFORMANCE AND THAT OF BENTLEY UNIVERSITY AGAINST APPROPRIATE GOALS ESTABLISHED ANNUALLY BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE, IN ITS SOLE DISCRETION, MAY DETERMINE NOT TO AWARD A BONUS FOR ANY GIVEN YEAR. TORREY, PAGE, CODY, LOGAN, MCKENNA, AND MALONE RECEIVED BONUS PAYMENTS. THE BONUSES ARE AWARDED BASED ON RECOMMENDATIONS MADE BY THE PRESIDENT AND ARE APPROVED BY THE COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS COMMITTEE WITH THE RATIONALE BASED UPON HER ASSESSMENT OF THE INDIVIDUAL'S PERFORMANCE.

DURING THE REPORTING PERIOD, PROFESSORS GALLIERS, MARKUS, BEDARD AND WIGGINS ALL PARTICIPATED IN ADDITIONAL FACULTY ROLES. THE AMOUNTS IN THIS COLUMN ARE NOT BONUS OR INCENTIVE COMPENSATION, BUT RATHER ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION FOR ADDITIONAL SERVICES PERFORMED.

Form 990, Schedule J, Part I Line 1 - The President of the College is provided a home in close proximity to the campus as a condition of his employment. The value of the residence provided to the President on campus has not been assigned a fair market value and is not included in Schedule J, Part II, Column (d). As required, the College provides cleaning and maintenance services for the employer provided housing. The college occasionally requires the travel, at various business functions, of the President's spouse (who is also a part-time employee of the College, but whose compensation did not exceed $10,000 and therefore is not required to be disclosed on Schedule L) and the VP for Advancement's spouse. Travel depends on the nature of the function and the duties of the spouses are determined in advance and approved. In such instances full substantiation of the expenses is also required. Finally, the College pays the social club membership dues of the President, the Vice President of Finance, and the Vice President for Advancement so that they may host donors and other business guests of the College at activities designed to benefit the College. To the extent that these individuals incur any personal expenses related to their social club usage, they are required to reimburse the College. All business expenditures must be substantiated to be excluded from their wages. Line 4a - Vice President of Administration, Dave Dentler, received a severance payment of $76,444 in calendar year 2013. This amount has been reported in Schedule J, part II, column (b)(iii).

DETERMINING COMPENSATION OF ITS PRESIDENT AND SENIOR MANAGEMENT INCLUDES A MARKET ANALYSIS USING COMPENSATION SURVEYS FROM PROFESSIONAL ORGANIZATIONS SUCH AS CUPA, AS WELL AS THE DIVISION OF LABOR STATISTICS FOR SALARIES IN THE 25%-50% PERCENTILE FOR COLLEGES SIMILAR TO THE ELMS. THIS INFORMATION IS COMPARED TO MANAGEMENT'S COMPENSATION BASED ON JOB TITLE, JOB DESCRIPTION, AND JOB EXPERIENCE TO DETERMINE WHETHER THE COLLEGE'S COMPENSATION IS COMPARABLE. THE PRESIDENT'S SALARY IS THEN DETERMINED AND APPROVED BY THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES. SENIOR MANAGEMENT SALARIES ARE EVALUATED AND APPROVED BY THE PRESIDENT AND THEN SENT TO THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE FOR APPROVAL.

WELLESLEY COLLEGE'S POLICY IS THAT THE COLLEGE WILL NOT PAY FOR - OR REIMBURSE - TRAVEL, MEALS, AND EXPENSES OF THE SPOUSE/PARTNER OF AN EMPLOYEE WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE PRESIDENT. SPECIFICALLY, WHILE PERFORMING HER OFFICIAL DUTIES IN THE AREAS OF DEVELOPMENT, ALUMNAE RELATIONS, AND OTHER BUSINESS OF THE COLLEGE, THE PRESIDENT MAY BE ACCOMPANIED BY HER SPOUSE, WHO IS EXPECTED TO MAKE AN IMPORTANT CONTRIBUTION TO ACHIEVING THE PURPOSES OF THE TRAVEL OR EVENTS. IN THOSE CASES, THE COLLEGE'S POLICY IS TO AUTHORIZE THE PAYMENT OF ALL TRAVEL AND RELATED EXPENSES OF THE PRESIDENT'S SPOUSE. THE COLLEGE PROVIDES HOUSING TO CERTAIN EMPLOYEES AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT FOR THE CONVENIENCE AND BENEFIT OF THE COLLEGE. THE HOUSING REQUIREMENT AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT IS DOCUMENTED IN THE EMPLOYEES' FILES. THE COLLEGE WILL NOT PAY FOR PERSONAL SERVICES WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE. BECAUSE THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE IS USED EXTENSIVELY FOR COLLEGE BUSINESS, HOUSEKEEPING SERVICES ARE PROVIDED FOR THE GENERAL SPACE. A CHEF WILL BE AT THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE TO PROVIDE MEALS FOR BUSINESS PURPOSE FUNCTIONS.

Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a, First-class or charter travel
ExplntnTxt: THE UNIVERSITY'S WRITTEN TRAVEL POLICY PERMITS PAYMENT ONLY OF NECESSARY AND REASONABLE EXPENSES FOR TRAVEL ON UNIVERSITY BUSINESS. THE UNIVERSITY'S POLICIES CONSTITUTE AN ACCOUNTABLE PLAN AND ARE DESIGNED TO COMPLY WITH APPLICABLE INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE RULES. COACH CLASS AIRFARE IS REQUIRED EXCEPT IN CERTAIN LIMITED CIRCUMSTANCES; THESE INCLUDE MEDICAL NECESSITY, CONTRACTUAL OBLIGATIONS, AND SCHEDULED FLIGHT SEGMENTS OVER SIX HOURS IN LENGTH, WHEN BUSINESS CLASS FARES MAY BE USED WITH PRIOR APPROVAL. IN RARE CASES, WHEN AN EXCEPTION APPLIES AND NO BUSINESS CLASS FARE IS AVAILABLE, A FIRST CLASS FARE MAY BE USED, AGAIN WITH PRIOR APPROVAL AND DOCUMENTATION. CHARTER TRAVEL IS SOMETIMES EMPLOYED FOR ATHLETICS TEAMS, INCLUDING COACHES, WHEN SUCH TRAVEL IS THE LEAST COSTLY METHOD OF TRANSPORTATION.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a, Travel for companions
ExplntnTxt: UNDER THE UNIVERSITY'S TRAVEL POLICY, THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT PAY THE TRAVEL COST OF COMPANIONS, UNLESS THERE IS A VALID UNIVERSITY BUSINESS PURPOSE FOR THE COMPANION'S TRAVEL. WRITTEN APPROVAL MUST BE OBTAINED IN ADVANCE FROM THE APPROPRIATE DEAN OR VICE PRESIDENT DOCUMENTING THE REASON FOR INCURRING THE EXPENSE. WHEN THE UNIVERSITY USES CHARTERED AIR OR GROUND TRANSPORTATION, TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS MAY OCCASIONALLY BE PROVIDED IF THE UNIVERSITY INCURS NO ADDITIONAL COST.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 3, Arrangement used to establish the top management official's compensation
ExplntnTxt: THE CORD (COMPENSATION AND ORGANIZATIONAL DEVELOPMENT) COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF RICE UNIVERSITY HAS A WRITTEN PROCEDURE IN PLACE TO ASSURE THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES THAT COMPENSATION ARRANGEMENTS FOR THE PRESIDENT AND OTHER ORGANIZATION OFFICERS AND MANAGERS ARE REASONABLE. THE PROCEDURE IS DESIGNED TO COMPLY WITH THE REQUIREMENTS OF SECTION 4958 OF THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE AND INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE REGULATIONS. THE CORD COMMITTEE MAINTAINS A ROSTER OF DISQUALIFIED PERSONS, AS DEFINED BY THE IRS, FOR WHOSE COMPENSATION THE PROCEDURE IS USED. THE ROSTER IS REVISED PERIODICALLY BUT AT LEAST ANNUALLY. THE PROCEDURE WAS DISCUSSED WITH THE FULL BOARD IN MARCH 2011. THE PROCEDURE REQUIRES THREE ELEMENTS AS FOLLOWS: 1) THE TERMS OF TRANSACTIONS ARE APPROVED BY THE ORGANIZATION'S GOVERNING BODY, OR A COMMITTEE THEREOF, WHOSE MEMBERS HAVE NO CONFLICT OF INTEREST WITH RESPECT TO THE ARRANGEMENT. THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES DELEGATED AUTHORITY TO THE CORD COMMITTEE TO ACT ON BEHALF OF THE BOARD IN THESE MATTERS AT ITS MEETING ON MARCH 25, 1999. COMPENSATION ARRANGEMENTS ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY THE CORD COMMITTEE BEFORE THE EFFECTIVE DATE. MEMBERS OF THE CORD COMMITTEE RECUSE THEMSELVES FROM ANY VOTE IN WHICH THERE IS A POTENTIAL OR ACTUAL CONFLICT OF INTEREST. 2) THE GOVERNING BODY OR COMMITTEE OBTAINS AND RELIES UPON APPROPRIATE, COMPARABLE DATA BEFORE MAKING ITS DETERMINATION. RICE PARTICIPATES IN THE ANNUAL SURVEY BY TOWERS WATSON OF SELECT UNIVERSITIES' EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION, AND ADDITIONAL APPROPRIATE PEER SURVEYS. THESE REPORTS REFLECT EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION IN UNIVERSITIES OF A STATURE SIMILAR TO THAT OF RICE, AND WITH WHICH RICE COMPETES FOR FACULTY AND STAFF. THE CORD COMMITTEE MAY ALSO SEEK AND RELY ON OTHER RELEVANT INFORMATION, INCLUDING COMPENSATION PAID BY OTHER TAXABLE AND TAX-EXEMPT ORGANIZATIONS FOR FUNCTIONALLY COMPARABLE POSITIONS, GEOGRAPHIC MARKET FORCES, AND ACTUAL WRITTEN OFFERS FROM SIMILAR INSTITUTIONS COMPETING FOR SERVICES. THE CORD COMMITTEE RELIES ON THIS DATA AND DOCUMENTS ANY DETERMINATIONS THAT REASONABLE COMPENSATION IS AN AMOUNT MORE THAN THE RANGE OF COMPARABLE DATA. 3) THE GOVERNING BODY OR COMMITTEE ADEQUATELY DOCUMENTS THE BASIS FOR MAKING DETERMINATIONS CONCURRENTLY WITH MAKING DECISIONS. MINUTES DOCUMENTING THE DELIBERATIONS OF THE CORD COMMITTEE ARE PREPARED CONTEMPORANEOUSLY FOR REVIEW AND APPROVAL AT ITS NEXT MEETING.

TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS: According to the University policy, travel for the spouse of the University's president shall only be reimbursed if incurred while conducting business of the University. Such reimbursement requires substantiation as well as review and approval by the board of trustees prior to the reimbursement. During calendar year 2013, the University reimbursed President Lawrence for travel expenses incurred by his spouse while conducting business of the University. Such reimbursements were made in accordance with University policy. None of the reimbursements were treated as taxable compensation. TAX INDEMNIFICATION: President Lawrence's wages during calendar year 2013 were increased to cover the taxes for housing allowance, housekeeping services, personal use of automobile, and moving expenses. HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE: The University provided President Lawrence with housing as a condition of his employment. The housing is within close proximity to University campus and furnished for the benefit and convenience of the University to conduct University-related business and entertainment functions. The value of such housing is excludable from President Lawrence's taxable income under IRS Code Section 119 (d) and was included in his non taxable benefits amount reported on Schedule J, Part II, Column D. HEALTH OR SOCIAL CLUB DUES: According to the University policy, the University will reimburse certain senior management expenses. During calendar year 2013, the University provided health club due reimbursement to nine members of senior management. The amount paid by the University was included in the individuals' Form W-2 and reported on Schedule J, Part II, Column B(iii). PERSONAL SERVICES: According to the University policy, the University is responsible for maintaining the president's residence. The value of the housekeeping services provided to the residence that were personal in nature was included in his Form W-2 and reported on Schedule J. OTHER BUSINESS EXPENSES: The University reimburses its officers and key employees for ordinary and necessary business expenses incurred while conducting business of the University. Such reimbursement is made under an accountable plan and requires substantiation using the original expense documentations and approval by appropriate parties as authorized under University policy.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SEVERANCE OR CHANGE OF CONTROL PAYMENT
ExplntnTxt: The University has an employment and separation policy that covers members of the Senior Management Group, including some of the listed individuals. The severance provision ranges from 4 weeks to 16 weeks, depending on the term of employment. In addition, some of the listed individuals have a severance provision as part of their employment arrangement. The severance provision ranges from 12 months to 24 months. Other than the payments described below, no amounts were paid to the listed individuals during the calendar year ended December 31, 2013. Frances A. Drolette, Senior Vice President for Finance and Chief Financial Officer, left her position at the end of calendar year 2012. As part of her separation agreement, Ms. Drolette received a severance payment of $356,300, which was included in her W-2 and reported on Schedule J Part II Column B(iii). John Hose, Assistant Secretary of the Corporation, left his postition on 6/30/13. As part of his separation agreement, Mr. Hose received a severance payment of $93,758, which was included in his W-2 and reported on Schedule J Part II Column B(iii).

PART I, LINE 4B President Lawrence participates in a nonqualified deferred compensation arrangement under internal revenue code section 457(f). Provided President Lawrence is employed by the University, the University will credit a deferred compensation account each January 1. On January 1, 2013 the University credited President Lawrence's deferred compensation account $50,000. The amount is not vested or taxable and is included in Schedule J, Part II, Column C as deferred compensation. After serving as president of the University for over 16 years, Dr. Jehuda Reinharz retired from that position at the end of 2010 and continues to fulfill specified duties as president emeritus and a faculty member. Dr. Reinharz participated in a nonqualified deferred compensation retirement arrangement under Internal Revenue Code Section 457(f), including a supplemental executive retirement plan (SERP), designed to provide the equivalent of a pension benefit upon termination of service. No amounts were vested or paid during calendar year 2013 under the deferred compensation agreement.

SCHEDULE J, PART I, QUESTION 7 LEORA HARPAZ AND LEH-SHENG TANG RECEIVED PAYMENTS OF $225,518 AND 201,176 RESPECTIVELY. ANY TENURED FACULTY WITH 20 YEARS OF FULL-TIME CONTINUOUS SERVICE WHO IS AT LEAST 58 YEARS OF AGE AND NOT MORE THAN THE AGE TO RECEIVE FULL SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS HAS THE RIGHT TO PARTICIPATE. THE COMPENSATION IS BASED ON THE ELIGIBLE FACULTY MEMBER'S NINE-MONTH BASE CONTRACTED ACADEMIC SALARY. THE COMPENSATION IS ONE-TWELFTH OF HIS/HER ANNUAL SALARY, FOR EACH 1.5 YEARS OF FULL-TIME CONTINUOUS SERVICE NOT TO EXCEED $225,518. ANTHONY S. CAPRIO RECEIVED A BONUS OF $47,350 UNDER THE VARIABLE CASH COMPENSATION PLAN FOR THE PRESIDENT. THE PLAN IS DESIGNED TO RECOGNIZE THE INEQUITY IMPOSED ON HIGHER COMPENSATED INDIVIDUALS AS A RESULT OF THE IRS LIMIT ON QUALIFIED PLANS. THE VARIABLE CASH COMPENSATION CALCULATION IS THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN BASE COMPENSATION FOR THE PRIOR FISCAL YEAR AND THE CURRENT YEAR IRS COMPENSATION LIMIT IMPOSED UNDER CODE SECTION 401(A)(17). THE RATE APPLIED TO THE DIFFERENCE CALCULATED IS DETERMINED ANNUALLY BY THE UNIVERSITY COMPENSATION SUB-COMMITTEE. THE RATE IS BASED ON PERFORMANCE AND IS NOT TO EXCEED 20%.

Schedule J, Part I, Line 1: Discretionary Spending Account: The College Vice President for Institutional Advancement received a discretionary spending acccount in the form of an automobile allowance during calendar year 2013. The allowance is included in other reportable compensation in Schedule J, Part II, Column (B)(iii). Housing Allowance or Residence for Personal Use: The College provided the President with housing as a condition of her employment. The housing is on campus and furnished for the benefit and convenience to the college to conduct fundraising and other college-related business. The value of the housing is excludable from the President's taxable income under IRS code section 119(d) and was included in her nontaxable benefits reported on Schedule J, Part II, Column D. The Provost/Dean of Faculty and the Dean of the School of Business receive on campus housing as part of their employment contract. The current Professor of Chemistry held the position of Provost/Dean of the Faculty until 7/1/2013. The value of the housing was included in other reportable compensation in Schedule J, Part II, Column (B)(iii) for these individuals. Personal Services: On occasion, college employees perform routine cleaning and yard service for the President's on-campus residence related to college business. If required, the applicable amounts for the above items are reported as taxable compensation.

Schedule J, Part I, Line 4a: The College has entered into an employment arrangement with its President which includes a severance provision for compensation of up to one-year's salary upon severance without cause if certain conditions are met. there is no provision for change-in-control. No payments were made this year under this provision.

Compensation for certain individuals includes supplemental income related to services performed outside of the school year for research and other grant funded projects as provided by the grant source.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Form 990, Schedule J and Form 990, Part VII:
ExplntnTxt: Compensation for officers, directors, key employees and the top five highest compensated employees is reported on both Schedule J and Form 990, Part VII. As required by the instructions for Form 990, column (b) of Schedule J, Part II reports the compensation reported on the individual's Form W-2 for the 2013 calendar year. In addition, column (c) of Schedule J, Part II reports deferred compensation earned by each individual during the 2013 calendar year, whether the individual actually received this compensation or not. Column (D) of Schedule J, Part II reports the non-taxable benefits received by the individual during the 2013 calendar year. Lastly, column (e) of Schedule J, Part II reports the total compensation received by the individual during the 2013 calendar year.

Out-of-town Board members that choose to bring a companion to the annual meeting are provided a letter outlining expenses incurred by the University for that companion. The Board member is expected to provide that letter to his/her tax accountant. Expenses include airfare, meals and expenses for special events.

CONTINGENT COMPENSATION THE ORGANIZATION'S REVENUES AND NET EARNINGS ARE TAKEN INTO CONSIDERATION WHEN CALCULATING EXECUTIVE INCENTIVE COMPENSATION IN ADDITION TO OTHER NON-FINANCIAL FACTORS. EXECUTIVE INCENTIVE COMPENSATION IS DETERMINED BY SEVERAL KEY METRICS THAT ARE ESTABLISHED BY THE NEBRASKA MEDICAL CENTER BOARD OF DIRECTORS. THESE METRICS ARE INCLUSIVE OF STRATEGIC, FINANCIAL, OPERATIONAL AND QUALITY OUTCOMES. ON AN ANNUAL BASIS, THE NEBRASKA MEDICAL CENTER BOARD OF DIRECTORS REVIEWS ACHIEVEMENT OF PRESET TARGETS AND APPROVES INCENTIVES WHEN WARRANTED. THESE PERFORMANCE PAYMENTS ARE IN LIEU OF A TYPICAL EXECUTIVE'S BASE PAY. EMPLOYEES ARE REIMBURSED FOR BUSINESS EXPENSES THAT RELATE TO THE PRACTICE OF MEDICINE. THE TOTAL AMOUNT REIMBURSABLE IN A GIVEN FISCAL YEAR IS DETERMINED BY THE RESPECTIVE CHAIRPERSON. ALL REIMBURSEMENTS ARE SUBJECT TO APPROVAL BY THE CHAIRPERSON OR THEIR DESIGNEE. FOR AN EXPENSE TO BE ELIGIBLE FOR REIMBURSEMENT, IT MUST BE ALLOWABLE "IN ACCORDANCE WITH GENERALLY ACCEPTED ACCOUNTING PRINCIPLES AND ALLOWABLE TO A PRACTITIONER AS A DEDUCTIBLE COST OR EXPENSE UNDER CURRENT FEDERAL INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE GUIDELINES." DOCUMENTATION OF EXPENSES FOLLOWS IRS GUIDELINES. EXPENSES ARE NOT PROCESSED UNLESS THEY HAVE COMPLETE DOCUMENTATION. EXPENDITURES THAT ARE $25,000 OR GREATER, UNPRECEDENTED, OR UNUSUAL, WILL REQUIRE PRIOR APPROVAL FROM THE PURCHASING AND ASSET MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE.

The University President lives in university owned property. The President is provided with a health club membership and spousal travel occurs periodically.

Compensation for the university president is set by the board of trustees based on a recommendation from the compensation committee of the board. The compensation committee consists of three members of the executive committee of the board. The committee gathers input from independent sources, including comparative university data. The President's compensation is then approved by the university trustees as well as by the sponsoring church denomination via its executive committee. The university chairperson, on behalf of the full board, signs the President's annual statement of salary and benefits.

AT LEAST ONE OF THESE TRIPS IS USUALLY WHEN THE PRESIDENT ATTENDS GRADUATION CEREMONIES HELD IN THE UNIVERSITYS FOREIGN LOCATIONS. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO PAYS FOR THE PRESIDENTS MEMBERSHIP AT THE BELLEVUE CLUB (HEALTH AND SOCIAL CLUB THAT HAS RESTAURANTS AND A HOTEL WITHIN THE CLUB) WHERE THE PRESIDENT OCCASIONALLY ENTERTAINS BUSINESS ASSOCIATES. THESE BENEFITS ARE TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION. THE PRESIDENT IS THE ONLY PERSON WHO RECEIVED SUCH BENEFITS. LEE GORSUCH PARTICIPATES IN A 457B RETIREMENT PLAN IN LIEU OF RECEIVING EMPLOYER PAID BENEFITS SUCH AS MEDICAL, DENTAL, VISION,EAP, AND LIFE INSURANCE. THE UNIVERSITY PAID $5,891 INTO THIS PLAN DURING THE CALENDAR YEAR 2013, WHICH IS ALSO INCLUDED IN BOX 5 OF HIS W-2 (TAXABLE WAGES). FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Part I, Line 1a: Relevant information in regards to selections on 1a.
ExplntnTxt: FIRST CLASS OR CHARTER TRAVEL - the president is permitted to travel by first class airfare in limited circumstances per university policy. First class travel costs is not considered taxable compensation. TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS - Travel costs of companions of university trustees, officers, and key employees are reimbursed in limited circumstances and such reimbursement is considered taxable income to the trustee, officer, or key employee unless the companion's travel would otherwise be considered deductible under the Internal Revenue Code. Any such taxable reimbursements to companions of university officers are included in Schedule J, Part II, column (B)(iii). TAX INDEMNIFICATION & GROSS UP PAYMENTS - Tax gross-up payments, considered taxable compensation, were provided to 4 officers and key employees listed in Part II of Schedule J for one or more of the following items:(a) taxable tuition remission benefits; or (b) years of service recognition awards. HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE - The university requires the president and provost to reside in a specific campus housing. The estimated fair rental value of the personal living space, including utilities, is not considered taxable income since on-campus residency is an employment requirement imposed by the university. The estimated fair value is included in Schedule J.HEALTH OR SOCIAL CLUB DUES OR INITIATION FEES - Certain employees have golf memberships at the university owned golf course. In addition, the university pays membership dues at certain private establishments for the purpose of holding business or fundraising events.PERSONAL SERVICES-Certain facilities and maintenance staff have primary responsibilities for the upkeep of the campus building in which the president resides. Those duties include from time to time cooking, cleaning, and driving/chauffeur duties for the president to maximize the president's time devoted to university business. The allocable costs of these employee duties are not considered taxable compensation to the president.
